The world is being horrid to you right now. ai hope the treatments are not to bad and that you will be cancer free(of both!!!) soon. Suzanne

Posts.Title: Houston Conference information gracem gracem

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2011 08:41PM gracem wrote: Hi all, I survived my first day. Spent about 20 min with doc and 15 min with 2 research nurses and spent 6 and a half hours waiting. i don't mind the waiting, i know that comes with the territory, but why am I so tired after doing nothing? There are 2 phase II clinical trials that I may be a candidate for, one we won't know until I have a biopsy. I had a liver biopsy in Nov, but they have to have a fresh one. The other they can test my old tissue to see if I qualify, but then you need 2 biopsies and lots of visits in the first month. Before I consider those trials, I need to get into to see the targeted therapy clinic (stage 1 trials) to see what they may offer. I am intrigued with the belief here that you should have as much targeted therapy as possible and as early as possible. The onc seemed to think if I went on to the next standard chemo, yes it may keep my cancer at bay for awhile, but my qol would only go down especially concerning fatigue. He feels the more chemo you get the more fatigued you will become and thus lower qol. With targeted therapies, the issues are much different.  He would have suggested getting a biopsy to map my genome (thus knowing what targeted therapies may work) after 2 standard chemos have failed. Four have failed me so far. My frustration is that none of my next appts are made yet. I need to wait to hear when I have CT/PET, appt with tageted therapy clinic and possibly a biopsy. God knows when all that may happen. You know I want those appts yesterday! On a lighter note, we have met lot of nice people here from all over. It's like coming to the cancer mother land and I am with my people. Wigs, ports and other various contraptions sticking out of body parts abound. We had a very nice dinner at a mexican/cuban restaurant in Rice Village. The van driver recommended it and the plantains( and the mojito) were fabulous.  Thanks for all the advice. Fill you in tomorrow. Need to find some mindless television (Housewifes??) and forget about cancer for a bit. Suzanne

We'd love to pick your brain about the Targeted Therapy clinic. I have an appt with Dr Whelan for Tues. Not sure if we'll stay the weekend or not. Depends when they give me my pet/ct scan appt. Spent the day at the Galleria. At least we got lots of walking in! Hope u r doing well Suzanne
Posts.Title: Arrived at MDA, we're not in New England anymore! gracem pharmgirl

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2011 07:28PM gracem wrote: Gigi, Hoping for some great results for you. Scanxiety sucks. Have fun in Atlantic City.  Try no to look at the results. They will be there to deal with when you get back. Have a few cosmos :) and enjoy your time with family. Best wishes! Suzanne
Posts.Title: mounting SCANXIETY mamanmidwife Moderators

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2011 09:10AM gracem wrote: Hi All, Had a GREAT day yesterday! First of all, got to meet Rachel (pharmgirl). She is beautiful and so gracious. I never would have found my way around without her and she gave me such good advice. She came to meet us between appts and we ended up going to the Targeted Therapy Clinic together for our appts. We have the same doctor who is wonderful. That clinic is truly amazing. They have 100 clinical trials going on there. All based on targeting your tumor. Yes, they are phase 1 which is scary, but a lot of times they are using proven drugs but in different ways. It just makes so much sense to do things this way rather than just one chemo after the other. I wish clinics like this were available everywhere. Dr Wheler actually suggested to me the same trial Rachel is on. (arimidex plus everolimus). There has been a lot in the news lately about this drug and it's effectiveness on bc so I am thrilled to try it. Meanwhile, they will test my tumor's genetic info to see what other pathways or targets I may have for other trials in the future. I am so happy not to start another chemo again (at least for awhile). I need to come back on the 19th to start the trial and get my months supply of everolimus. Then monthly visits which won't be easy, but if it is working I will do it!  Rachel and her wonderful husband Clint were so kind to offer to take my husband and I to dinner to get some great mexican food. (Hard to find in CT!). The fajitas (and the company) were out of this world. I've never been to a place where they make their own tortillas. We fly home tomorrow. I definitely feel this trip was worth all the hassle. MD Anderson is a unique and amazing place. Thank you so much Rachel and Clint for your kindness and hospitality. I am so happy to have been able to meet you. I get to see my kids tomorrow! Yeah! Suzanne
Posts.Title: Arrived at MDA, we're not in New England anymore! gracem pharmgirl

Hoepfully we'll get to a grocery store to stock up on a few things. I have to draw the line somewhere and $2.25 for a bottle of water out of the vending machine is it. I hope the MDA water is good and healthy because I won't be buying water out of the machines. It is nice to have the patient liasons  right in the lobby.  Very nervous about my first appt tomorrow.A lot riding on this you could say. Wish me luck Suzanne  Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2011 01:00AM gracem wrote: I agree. making changes early is not the normal procedure or our "marathon". It was also explained to me to think of mets changes as an ear infection. If you got an antibiotic the very first day you notice it, the antibiotic will take care of it. If you wait until it is very painful, the antibiotic will still take care of it. If you are on a med that is working, it will work whether you have one spot or 3. Getting it earlier if there is no real danger, will not make a difference in the end and may cause you to use up your options earlier than needed. I just re read that, I am not explaining it well.  Sorry.

Posts.Title: How do I cope with mets...anyone want to teach the 101 class?? AlaskaDeb slonedeb

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2008 10:46AM gracem wrote: Deb, So sorry you are dealing with this. Is there anything harder? It totally sucks. Give yourself sometime to "wallow". Acceptance takes time.It's certainly OK to feel scared, mad, defeated, tired etc etc. Then finally one day you'll realize that you feel pretty OK  and start to live your life under the cloud. As many others have told me, you have entered a marathon. There is no finish line in the near future. You are now living with cancer. I have had mets since the beginning 3 and a half years ago. I kept waiting for it to be over and move on and go back to my old life. I realized that I needed to accept that this was my life now. And how much of that life did I want Cancer to control? It will take as much as you allow it, believe me. How did I want my kids (4 and6) to see me? I take my meds and go to my appts and feel tired and achey some of the time, but it won't keep me from enjoying my kids and planning vacations and volunteering. I've had to cut back on some things and nap once in awhile. I bought the cupcakes for my son's school B-day party instead of making them like I normally would, but who cares? It is as much if not more difficult for me right now to deal with the psychological burden than the physical stuff. I know things and people that trigger me and I avoid them. I also believe denial is a good thing to a certaine extent. You will find your way through this and you will be happy again. Hang in there. So many of us have been through this tunnel and come out the other side. We will even pull you through it! Be kind to yourself! Suzanne
Posts.Title: How do I cope with mets...anyone want to teach the 101 class?? AlaskaDeb slonedeb

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2009 11:53AM gracem wrote: More details on the Howard Johnson's Hotel at Fenway: Hi all, Here are a few more details on the Howard Johnson's Fenway. The rate if $115 a night plus $20 parking (if you have a car). They CAN use the bus the next day if it is not full of patients, which it never has been. This is for Friday night only. They are sold out Saturday night. The confirmation number is G0001206. Since there are so few rooms, people should book pretty quickly. Callers must say they want the rate for the Metastatic Breast Cancer Conference on Saturday. They should know the rate is $115 plus tax; $20 additional if they park a car.

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2011 02:39PM gracem wrote: I too resisted the port for almost 5 years of mbc treatments. It wasn't until they wanted to start navelbine that they said i had to get it. Navelbine is a vesicant and if it leaks out of the vessel, it can cause tissue damage. I've had my port since Nov and have a love/hate relationship. Love that I know I never have to get stuck more than the once. I also get numbing spray because I am a big baby and hardly feel a thing. The hate comes from the general freak out of feeling this plastic thing in my chest that is hooked into my vein. Yuck. This is my first summer with the port so realized I needed a cover for my seatbelt and some shirts show more port than others. Hey! Like my grey hairs, I earned this port and people can stare. Who cares! As for the navelbine, it was not tough at all. Once in awhile my wbc were too low and i needed neupogen. I was fatigued, but very tolerable. Good Luck!!! Suzanne

Posts.Title: thinking of heading to MD Anderson for consultaton gracem PJB

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2011 02:07PM gracem wrote: Thank you everyone. You have given me great advice. I have been franticly getting my records to my MDA coordinator. She should have everything now, so hopefully tomorrow she will give me an appt? I feel like I am trying to see the Pope. I understand their process, but really, going there will mean thousands of dollars to them. Why do they make it so hard to get an appt?  They wanted my "chemo flow sheets". They already had all my doctor's notes. I asked my onc today at my appt and she said she doesn't do chemo flow sheets. She showed me how at every visit the notes begin with my current meds, past chemos etc. The coordinator said to me it is very "unusual" that my doctor doesn't do them. OK, so what am I supposed to do? My doctor DOESN"T do them!! I ended up having my chemo nurse send a copy of her notes from every visit that I had chemo. Another 86 pages of notes. God, please let this be enough info for them to finally give me a &^*#^& appt!!!!! Sorry to vent, but I just want to know when I can go so I can book flight, get kids to grandparents, dog to kennel etc etc. I'll keep u all up to date on my saga. Suzanne ps Fitz, I do go to Dana Farber but they have nothing to offer me now other than the standard treatments and i am looking for a clinical trial or something novel. I have had a lot of chemo in the past 2 years and soon I won't qualify for many trials because of too many lines of treatment.Phase 1 's often don't limit lines of treatment, but I don't know that I am ready to consider a phase 1.

Posts.Title: Liver NED! Bruburn jenn3

Posts.Content: gracem wrote: Hi all, I just wanted to share that I talked to a woman yesterday who was diagnosed in 1986 with BC that had already spread to the spine. I asked when she was diagnosed and she said "1986" then I asked when she was diagnosed as metastatic and she said "1986!". I nearly fell off my chair! She was in her 30's then and knew she had a lump but no one thought anything of it. She then started having back pain and went to a chiropractor. When she still didn't improve she went to a spine surgeon who did an x-ray and saw something and finally the lump was excised and found to be BC. She had her ovaries removed, radiation and hormonals. She now has several small bone mets, but nothing urgent and gets zometa. In 1986 she was told she had 18mos to live. It just totally made my day talking with her and I wanted to share with you all. Anything is possible!!!!!!!!! Suzanne Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: gracem wrote: Pink Ribbon Month Is Coming Once again in October, there will be a wall of pink with marches, walks and rallies as thousands of individuals with primary breast cancer are feted, cheered and honored. Yet, one third of those diagnosed with breast cancer will not be seen or heard.  Hidden away in the shadows - misunderstood, feared, isolated, ignored - will be 155,000 of us who live day to day with stage 4 disease.   OUR REALITY IS RARELY DISCUSSED AT THESE BREAST CANCER EVENTS LET YOUR VOICE BE HEARD...again! Thanks to your efforts last year, we obtained proclamations from Mayors in 31 cities and Governors in 9 states declaring October 13th   Metastatic Breast Cancer Awareness Day.  We are excited to report that we now anticipate receiving a National Resolution to declare October 13th  Metastatic Breast Cancer Awareness Day.    OUR WORK IS NOT YET DONE   Due to your efforts, there were news reports written and some members appeared on TV and talk radio.  Our voice was heard ...  but not loud enough!  We still need your help on a local level because local media care most about local people. Getting that local proclamation and telling your hometown newspaper, radio or TV station your story will further heighten awareness of metastatic disease.        MBCN has prepared an informational packet designed to make it easy for you to contact your mayor's office to get METASTATIC BREAST CANCER AWARENESS DAY proclaimed in your city. Say YES to having your voice heard! Say YES to contacting your mayor! MBCN is here to help you get started on PHASE ONE of our Awareness Day outreach.  Respond to getinvolved.mbcnet@gmail.com . PUT  THE NAME OF YOUR CITY AND STATE IN THE SUBJECT LINE of the email. In the body of your response, please include your full name, city, state and phone number. Within a week, we will begin emailing the Metastatic Breast Cancer Awareness Day step-by-step package to all who respond.  This is PHASE ONE of our Awareness Day outreach. More to come.... www.mbcnetwork.org Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Let Our Voices Be Heard in October gracem glow

Posts.Title: rough day pattih pattih

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2009 10:10PM gracem wrote: Wow janis, I feel your pain. The absolute hardest part of dealing with this disease is the emotional toll it takes on my family. I have a DD8 and DS6. I've had stage 4 for 5 years so it's not new to them, but I think they inderstand more now. My DD is pretty good about talking to me, asking Q's etc. I always reassure her that she is loved by many many people.She will always be taken  care of. Mommy and her doctors are doing everything they can to keep me healthy, but I will always have cancer and be on treatment. I am starting to realize how closely she watches me and she seems to get anxious if I am in pain or need to rest. This puts more pressure on me not to show how I feel. Ugh. My son is the enigma.He nevers talks about it, but has major anxiety issues this school year and constantly complains of stomach pains and not wanting to eat.He's been checked out by the pedi and a gastro pedi  doc who say he is OK. What am I to think now other than it is his anxiety causing his symtoms? He has started to see the school social worker and I am looking for a child psych dr. As if we don't suffer enough in our own pain? Knowing the anxiety and pain it is causing my kids is just too much.  I will take any pain, any meds side effects etc. just please please leave my kids out of it. Suzanne

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2011 06:10PM gracem wrote: I too was diagnosed at stage 4 from the start. Had dose dense chemo, lumpectomy then mastectomy. The reasoning was to reduce tumor load since the size of the tumor left after initial chemo was still significant. Studies since then have shown it is beneficial and after 6+ years with mets, I guess I agree. Suzanne
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy even at stage IV??? mommyx3 MJLToday
